title: 77 Bank Gives Loan for 52.5MW Solar Project in Fukushima
text:
77 Bank Gives Loan for 52.5MW Solar Project in Fukushima 77 Bank Gives Loan for 52.5MW Solar Project in Fukushima 2015/10/02 17:10 Kenji Kaneko, Nikkei BP CleanTech Institute An image of the plant (source: Marubeni) 
The 77 Bank Ltd announced Sept 28, 2015, that it has structured a syndicated loan of ¥15.8 billion (approx US$132 million) through project financing for a 52.5MW solar power plant to be built in Isobe District, Soma City, Fukushima Prefecture, and concluded a loan contract. 
The arranger of the loan is The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ Ltd, and 77 Bank is a co-arranger. Five banks participated in the syndicated loan. 
The project will be the largest-scale solar power generation project that is included in a reconstruction plan made by Soma City and uses an area affected by a tsunami in the Tohoku region of Japan. Of the total loan amount (¥15.8 billion), 77 Bank will provide the largest share (¥6.8 billion). 
The power producer for the project is "Renatosu Soma Solar Park LLC," an SPC (special purpose company) owned 40% by Kyudenko Corp, 30% by Orix Corp, 19.8% by Beltecno Energy (Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo), 10% by Kyuden Mirai Energy Co Inc (Fukuoka City) and 0.2% by Hokuto Denki Setsubi Kouji (Minamisoma City, Fukushima Prefecture). 
The construction of the plant started in July 2015, and the plant is scheduled to start power generation in June 2017. The plant is expected to generate about 60,000,000kWh of electricity, which is equivalent to the amount consumed by 16,660 households, per year. All of the electricity generated will be sold to Tohoku-Electric Power Co Inc. 
Kyudenko Hokuto Denki Specific Construction Joint Venture and Kyudenko provide EPC (engineering, procurement and construction) and O&M (operation and maintenance) services, respectively, for the plant. Marubeni Corp will deliver about 198,000 solar panels manufactured by Hanwha Q Cells Co Ltd to the plant. The PV inverter employed for the plant is a product of Toshiba Mitsubishi-Electric Industrial Systems Corp (TMEIC). 
Isobe District, which is the construction site, was damaged by a tsunami at the time of the Great East Japan Earthquake, and it became difficult to do faming there due to salt damage. As a result, the land category of the district was permitted to be changed from farmland in March 2015. Solar panels will be set up on about 700,000m 2 of land including part of Isobe Aza Seriyachi ( See related article ).
